questions.text: Which of the following viruses does not belong to the family of Picornaviridae?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Among the given options, Hepatitis C virus does not belong to the picornaviridae family.
  • Picornaviruses are a large virus family with many members but are among the smallest in virion size and genetic complexity.
  • They are non-enveloped, icosahedral viruses with positive sense, single stranded RNA
  • The major human pathogens within the picornaviridae family are enteroviruses and rhinoviruses.(Option A ruled out)
  • Enteroviruses temporarily inhabit the human gastrointestinal tract and can be isolated from the throat or lower intestine, while rhinoviruses are linked to respiratory tract infections and are chiefly isolated from the nose and throat.
  • The most severe enterovirus-caused disease is poliomyelitis. (Option C ruled out)
  • Other less common human-infecting picornaviruses include hepatitis A virus, parechovirus, cardiovirus, and Aichi virus.
  • These viruses can cause human illnesses ranging from severe paralysis to aseptic meningitis, pleurodynia, myocarditis, vesicular and exanthematous skin eruptions
  • The virions of enteroviruses and rhinoviruses have a capsid with 60 subunits, each made of four proteins (VP1-VP4) arranged icosahedrally around a single-stranded, positive-sense RNA genome.
  • The Picornaviridae family contains 12 genera, including Enterovirus, Hepatovirus, Kobuvirus, Parechovirus, Cardiovirus, and Aphthovirus.
  • The first five genera have major human pathogens. Rhinoviruses, once a separate genus, are now classified under Enterovirus.
  • Coxsackie A viruses are within HEV-A and HEV-C and coxsackie B and echoviruses fall into HEV-B. (Option B ruled out)
  • Hepatitis A virus, once an enterovirus type 72, is now in its own genus.

questions.text: Which antigenic type of polio is responsible for Vaccine-associated paralytic poliomyelitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Antigenic type 3 is responsible for vaccine-associated paralytic poliomyelitis.
  • Poliomyelitis is an acute infectious disease that can affect the central nervous system in severe cases, leading to the destruction of motor neurons in the spinal cord and resulting in flaccid paralysis, though most infections are subclinical.
  • There are three antigenic types based on VP1, VP2, and VP3 epitopes. Of the three wild poliovirus types, types 2 and 3 have been eradicated worldwide, while type 1 remains in circulation in Afghanistan and Pakistan, with recent years also seeing outbreaks of circulating type 2 vaccine-derived poliovirus.
  • The virus enters via the mouth, multiplying initially in the oropharynx or intestine, and is present in the throat and stool before symptoms appear. Excretion in stools continues for weeks despite antibodies in the blood.
  • Most poliovirus infections are asymptomatic or inapparent. Following an incubation period of 3-6 days, about 5% of individuals develop a mild illness (abortive poliomyelitis) with symptoms such as fever, malaise, sore throat, anorexia, muscle aches, and headache, which typically resolve within 3 days.
  • Around 1% of cases present with aseptic meningitis (nonparalytic poliomyelitis), where cerebrospinal fluid examination shows lymphocytic pleocytosis, normal glucose levels, and normal or slightly elevated protein levels.
  • The poliovirus mainly targets motor neurons located in the anterior horn of the spinal cord and the cranial nerve nuclei within the medulla oblongata.
  • Muscle infection does not occur and damage in muscles is secondary to nerve cell destruction, with some recovery possible. Other pathology includes myocarditis, lymphatic hyperplasia, and Peyer's patch ulceration.
  • Clinically, infection can be inapparent, mild, or severe, with an incubation period of 7-14 days (range 3-35 days). Mild disease presents with low-grade fever, malaise, and nonspecific symptoms, resolving in days.
  • Nonparalytic poliomyelitis presents with stiffness and back or neck pain, usually resolving without paralysis. Paralytic poliomyelitis causes flaccid paralysis from lower motor neuron damage, with variable recovery. Progressive postpoliomyelitis muscle atrophy may occur decades later.
  • Laboratory diagnosis involves virus isolation from throat, rectal, or stool specimens. Cultures are inoculated into human or monkey cells, with cytopathic effects seen in 3-6 days. PCR may be used. Rising antibody titers confirm infection.
  • Immunity is permanent for the infecting type, mainly antibody-mediated, though heterotypic resistance is limited. Passive immunity is maternally transferred and wanes within months. Antibody formation occurs soon after exposure, often before symptoms.
  • Prevention uses inactivated (Salk) and live attenuated (Sabin) The inactivated vaccine induces humoral immunity but not intestinal immunity, while the live vaccine induces both systemic and mucosal immunity. The latter results in excretion of virus in the feces and results in herd immunity.
  • Live vaccines can revert to virulence, though rarely. Live vaccines should not be given to immunodeficient individuals.
  • Oral polio vaccine (OPV) is generally safe, but rare adverse events can occur, the most significant being vaccine-associated paralytic poliomyelitis (VAPP).
  • It can occur in both OPV recipients and their unvaccinated contacts, most often linked to Sabin 3, followed by Sabin 2 and Sabin 1. (Options A, B, and D ruled out)
  • Vaccine-derived polioviruses (VDPVs) are biologically similar to Wild polio viruses but differ from most vaccine-related poliovirus (VRPV) strains by possessing genetic traits that enable prolonged replication or transmission, lasting much longer than the typical 4-6 weeks in OPV recipients.

Explanation:

  • Pleurodynia is caused by Coxsackie B virus.
  • Coxsackieviruses are a major subgroup of enteroviruses that cause various human illnesses such as aseptic meningitis, respiratory infections, and febrile illnesses.
  • Specific conditions include herpangina, hand-foot-and-mouth disease, and acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis caused by certain group A serotypes, while pleurodynia, myocarditis, pericarditis, and severe generalized infant disease are linked to some group B serotypes. (Option C ruled out)
  • Both A and B serotypes can also cause meningoencephalitis and paralysis, though paralysis from non-polio enteroviruses is usually incomplete and reversible.
  • Coxsackie B viruses are the leading viral cause of human heart disease and are generally more pathogenic than echoviruses.
  • Infection begins with viral recovery from the blood in the early stages, and the virus is present in the throat early in illness and in stools for up to 5–6 weeks. The incubation period ranges from 2 to 9 days, and manifestations vary by serotype.
  • Aseptic meningitis, caused by all group B and many group A viruses, presents with fever, malaise, headache, nausea, and abdominal pain, sometimes progressing to muscle weakness.
  • Herpangina causes vesicular lesions on the posterior palate and throat, while hand-foot-and-mouth disease produces vesicular rashes on hands, feet, and mouth as shown below.
  • Pleurodynia causes sudden, intense chest or abdominal pain lasting days to weeks. Myocarditis, often from group B viruses, can be acute and life-threatening, particularly in infants.
  • Laboratory diagnosis involves virus recovery from throat or stool samples, with nasal secretions yielding the most virus in A21 infections. Detection methods include tissue culture, nucleic acid assays like RT-PCR, and serology for neutralizing antibodies, though serology is complicated by multiple virus types.
  • They occur more frequently in summer and early fall, especially in children without prior antibodies, and are easily spread within households.

Explanation of other options:

Poliovirus (Option A): Poliovirus infection can range from asymptomatic or mild febrile illness with symptoms like fever, malaise, headache, and sore throat to more severe forms such as nonparalytic aseptic meningitis, characterized by neck and back stiffness, and paralytic poliomyelitis, which causes flaccid paralysis from lower motor neuron damage.

Influenza virus (Option B): Influenza primarily affects the upper respiratory tract and poses higher risks for the elderly, young children, and those with chronic illnesses. Uncomplicated cases present suddenly with fever, chills, headache, dry cough, muscle aches, malaise, and anorexia, lasting a few days, though cough and weakness may persist for weeks. Severe cases, especially in vulnerable individuals, can lead to pneumonia.

questions.text: Which of the following viruses is the most common cause of common cold?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Rhinoviruses are the most common cause of common cold.
  • Rhinoviruses are the primary cause of the common cold and are frequently detected in mild upper respiratory illnesses.
  • They are most often recovered from nasopharyngeal secretions but can also be found in throat and oral secretions. Along with other respiratory viruses, they cause upper respiratory tract infections and account for about half of asthma exacerbations.
  • Over 150 types have been identified, classified into major and minor receptor groups, using ICAM-1 and LDLR respectively.
  • The virus enters through the upper respiratory tract, with high nasal secretion titers 2-4 days after exposure correlating with illness severity. Replication is confined to the nasal mucosa epithelium, producing edema and mild inflammation. The incubation period is 2-4 days, with illness lasting about a week, often with a lingering cough.
  • Adults usually have one or two colds per year, with symptoms such as sneezing, nasal congestion, discharge, sore throat, mild cough, malaise, and chills, but little or no fever. Secondary bacterial infections may lead to otitis media, sinusitis, bronchitis, or pneumonia.
  • Neutralizing antibodies develop in most people 7-21 days after infection, appearing in serum and nasal secretions, but immunity is incomplete and titers decline over time. The infection occurs worldwide, peaking in early fall and late spring, and is lowest in summer.
  • It spreads mainly through contact with contaminated respiratory secretions, often via hands and contaminated objects, with survival on surfaces for hours.
  • Infants and young children are most affected, and transmission within families is common.

Explanation of other options:

Influenza virus (Option A): Influenza mainly targets the upper respiratory tract and is particularly dangerous for older adults, young children, and people with chronic health conditions. Mild, uncomplicated illness begins abruptly with symptoms such as fever, chills, headache, dry cough, muscle pain, malaise, and loss of appetite, typically resolving within a few days, though cough and fatigue may linger for weeks. In more severe instances, especially among high-risk groups, it can progress to pneumonia.

Adenovirus (Option C): Adenoviruses commonly cause mild, self-limiting respiratory illnesses in children, occasionally affecting the eye and gastrointestinal tract, with serotypes 1-7 being most frequent. They can lead to conditions such as pneumonia, pharyngoconjunctival fever, epidemic keratoconjunctivitis, and gastroenteritis, while immunocompromised patients may develop severe or disseminated disease.

Measles virus (Option D): Measles in nonimmune individuals begins after an incubation of 8-15 days with a prodrome of fever, cough, coryza, conjunctivitis with photophobia, and Koplik spots followed by a characteristic rash starting on the face and spreading to the trunk and limbs. Complications include otitis media, pneumonia (viral or bacterial), giant cell pneumonia in immunocompromised patients, and neurological issues such as encephalitis or postinfectious encephalomyelitis.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy from a rural area in Assam presents in late summer with sudden-onset high-grade fever, headache, vomiting, and altered sensorium. On examination, he has neck stiffness and generalized hypertonia. CSF examination shows lymphocytic pleocytosis. Which of the following are the amplifying hosts for the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis based on the given clinical features of high-grade fever, altered sensorium, neck rigidity along with CSF examination revealing lymphocytic pleocytosis is suggestive of viral encephalitis caused most commonly in Asia by Japanese encephalitis for which pigs and birds act as amplifying hosts.
  • Japanese encephalitis (JE) is a mosquito-borne viral disease affecting humans as well as animals and is the leading cause of viral encephalitis in Asia.
  • Transmission is primarily through the night-biting mosquito Culex tritaeniorhynchus, which breeds abundantly in irrigated rice fields while pigs and birds act as amplifying hosts
  • Infections during the first and second trimesters of pregnancy have been linked to fetal death.
  • The incubation period is 4-15 days, and illness typically progresses through prodromal (2-3 days), acute (3-4 days), subacute (7-10 days), and convalescent (4-7 weeks) stages.
  • Symptoms may include abrupt fever, headache, malaise, anorexia, and diarrhea, progressing in severe cases to aseptic meningitis, meningoencephalitis, acute flaccid paralysis, and severe encephalitis.
  • Neurological signs include cerebellar signs, cranial nerve palsies, cognitive and speech impairments, Parkinsonian features, and seizures.
  • Rapidly changing neurological signs, such as alternating hyperreflexia and hyporeflexia or plantar response changes, are characteristic.
  • Mental status may deteriorate from confusion to coma, with fatal cases often leading to death within 10 days.
  • Laboratory findings include mild cerebrospinal fluid pleocytosis, initially polymorphonuclear then lymphocytic.
  • Diagnosis relies on detecting virus-specific IgM antibodies or demonstrating a fourfold rise in IgG titers in paired sera, or by PCR.
  • There is no specific antiviral treatment and management is supportive, including seizure control.

Explanation of other options:

Humans (Option A): Humans are incidental dead-end hosts; viremia is insufficient to infect mosquitoes. Hence, not amplifying hosts.

Rats (Option B): Not involved in the transmission cycle of Japanese Encephalitis.

Culex mosquito (Option D): Mosquitoes are the vectors, not amplifying hosts. They transmit infection between amplifying hosts and humans.

questions.text: Which WHO region has not been able to eradicate Polio virus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Wild polio virus is still transmitted in Afghanistan and Pakistan, both of which belong to the Eastern Mediterranean Region (EMR) of WHO.
  • Thus, EMR is the only region where polio remains endemic.
  • India, which belongs to the South-East Asia Region, eradicated polio in 2014, with the last case reported in 2011 (Howrah, West Bengal).
  • The European Region and Western Pacific Region were certified polio-free earlier.

Explanation of other options:

South-East Asia Region (Option A): Includes India, Nepal, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, Thailand, etc. Certified polio-free in 2014.

European Region (Option B): Certified polio-free by WHO in 2002.

Western Mediterranean Region (Option C): Not an official WHO classification; the recognized term is Eastern Mediterranean Region (EMR).
